thread.title: Flatland Film Festival continues with Friday documentary 'Barge'
thread.title_full: Flatland Film Festival continues with Friday documentary 'Barge'

author: William Kerns
title: Flatland Film Festival continues with Friday documentary 'Barge'
text:
Flatland Film Festival continues with Friday documentary 'Barge' Festival's Saturday shorts include film about sexual assaults on campus Posted: October 16, 2015 - 12:01am Photos PROVIDED BY TONJA HAGY-VALDINE "Barge," directed by Texas filmmaker Ben Powell, will be screened at 7:30 p.m. Friday at the Flatland Film Festival at LHUCA. Discovered at South by Southwest in Austin, "Barge" is a documentary about the people hoping to make money by working on a towboat headed for the port of New Orleans. By William Kerns A-J MEDIA ENTERTAINMENT EDITOR 
The 11th annual Flatland Film Festival will continue Friday and Saturday at LHUCA, 511 Ave. K, and at the Alamo Drafthouse Cinema, 120 W. Loop 289. 
Festival passes allow admittance to every festival event (early screenings, reception, Q&A and parties included). Passes are $30 and can be purchased in advance at flatlandfilm.org, or at the door. Individual events for those without passes at LHUCA are $15 for the general public and $10 for students. Individual events at the Alamo Drafthouse are $15. 
Call 762-8606 for more details. Full details about the festival also are at flatlandfilm.org. 
Being screened: 
■ 7:30 p.m. Friday, LHUCA Firehouse Theatre, documentary “Barge,” with Austin-based director Ben Powell attending. 
■ 9 p.m. Friday, Alamo Drafthouse, five independent short films. 
■ 10 p.m. Friday, Alamo Drafthouse, tongue-in-cheek horror film “Dude Bro Party Massacre III,” directed by Tomm Jacobsen, Michael Rousselet and Jon Salmon, with costar Greg Sestero attending. 
■ Midnight Friday, Alamo Drafthouse, psychological thriller/melodrama “The Room,” directed by Tommy Wiseau, with costar Greg Sestero attending. 
■ 7 p.m. Saturday, LHUCA Firehouse Theatre, “Flat Land and Open Skies: A Lubbock Music story,” documentary about musical history of Lubbock, directed by Paul Allen Hunton, Jonathan Seaborn and Daniel Ballard, all expected to attend. To be followed by a “surprise bonus screening.” 
Friday’s short films include: 
■ “The Sacred Journey, A Trip Through Peru,” directed by Shane Nassiri and narrated by Noemi Martinez, running time three minutes. 
■ “The Moon Man,” directed by Taylor Shofner, running time 15 minutes. 
■ “American Halloween,” directed by Brandon Carter, running time nine minutes. 
■ “The Incident,” directed by Jonathan Seaborn, Rachel Ballard and Daniel Ballard, running time 25 minutes. 
■ “Good Girls Don’t Tell, The Journeys of Survivors in Five Acts,” directed by Lindsey E. Blumell and Jennifer Huemmer, a 2015 documentary about survivors of sexual assault on college campuses. Huemmer and cinematographer-editor Selasi Kudowor will attend for a post-shorts Q&A session. The directors filmed actors cast as sexual assault victims, using precise transcripts from earlier interviews. Running time 42 minutes. 
All other short filmmakers are expected to attend the festival. 
william.kerns@lubbockonline.com
